description:
Saw an offer on Groupon and decided to give it a try since I'm new to the city and this combines all my favorites: sightseeing, hiking, yoga, fresh air and new people! I liked the route we took and all the spots we stopped for yoga were pretty. 

Weather was all over the place so wearing multiple layers was a good idea, jackets and scarfs kept coming on and off multiple times during the hike. 

Our guide Amy was super cute and friendly. There's lots of steep up and downhills as well as stairs so my calves really felt the exercise the next morning. We ended with a longer yoga session at the Coit Tower and also doing some partner yoga.

Can't wait for the next one!
author: Kat S.

description:
I found Hiking Yoga through a groupon deal (only $10 per person!).

I took my mom on Mother's Day! We took BART and got off Embarcadero and walked less than 5 minutes to meet up with everyone else at the Ferry Building under the clock tower at 9:50am. 

Laurie was our instructor and kindly checked us all in as we trickled in. We got in a circle to introduce ourselves and then started our hike. 

There was a total of 4 stops:

-The first stop was in a little grassy area. We started with some light stretches and breathing exercises. Then we went down Vallejo and started heading up on those steep hills. 

-The second stop was in a little neighborhood surrounded by trees and flowers. The view of the bay was gorgeous. This was my favorite spot. This is when it started getting super hot. I was dripping in sweat because of the sun beating down on me. We did some yoga stretches. 

-Our third destination was at an even higher hill overlooking the city. Laurie taught us some partner poses which I really enjoyed.

-Our last and final stop was at the Grace Cathedral, where we took a group picture together.

Afterwards, Laurie and her husband Scott led us back to where we started (for those who wanted to head back to the ferry building). Throughout the whole 1.5 hours, Laurie and Scott made sure to make conversations here and there with everyone (it was a group of about 20 people). They are such a sweet couple!

As for difficulty, I definitely expected it to be a little bit more challenging since I'm not very flexible, but it wasn't too bad, especially since there was more hiking than yoga-ing. As for my mom, she was super exhausted from climbing since she doesn't get out much.

All in all, I had a wonderful Sunday morning with a great group of people. I definitely would recommend Hiking Yoga! :)
author: Lincy H.

description:
I was just reminded of this great experience I took part of when I was in town for the Yelp 10 year anniversary. My trip was short and limited on the events I took part in, but I'm beyond glad that I this was one of listed (paid) events that were showcased for this gorgeous city. I like unconventional, nontraditional things and thought this fell into that. I enjoy both hiking and yoga but I don't think I would of ever looked into such an activity for a city type trip, otherwise. OMG, amazing...but soooo painful, in a good way...afterwards. ;)

So many wonderful things came out of this. I'm a big time walk about type of person and feel there's certain things that can only be appreciated while on foot.  San Francisco in general isn't car friendly to begin with. And though I've visited The City a few times before, I was able to really appreciate some really cool spots that are not quite known of.

So the hiking part...whoa, that was no joke. You want to be able to pace yourself with the pack and obviously there's going to be a mixed group of people. With that in mind, I will say you need to relatively be in good shape as there are hills and stairs (yep, those windy roads and stairs that SF is know for) that you'll have to tackle. The instructor/leader will not hesitate to keep going..so even if out of embarrassment, you're gonna  want to keep moving. Those inclines are what will make you feel the burn HARD but the feeling you get when you get to the top makes it all so worth it. That's when you'll have a chance to briefly catch your breath, do a Yoga pose, get centered and then take in a quick view (or pic) of the beautiful scene. You'll be overlooking the Golden Gate Bridge and Treasure Island at different secret points. We did 4 different poses which stretched over our 1 1/2 hour hike throughout the streets of SF. The hike will take you to pass through or stops at parks and landmarks such as the  Grace Cathedral Church, Coit Tower, which you'll end up at. 

This is seriously one of the coolest things you can do in this city. If all else, it'll give you an excuse to indulge afterwards in whatever those traditional things we all do while traveling. You know, all that eating and drinking stuff we likes to do.
author: Cat A.

description: Great way to see the city as a tourist and a local. Great workout, views and stretching. Having lived in the city for a couple of years prior to the hike, she still managed to take me to some hidden gems in my neighborhood. Hikes vary in ending location, but always starts at the Ferry Building.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Yes I'll admit it... My Groupon addiction led me to Hiking Yoga, and I'm so glad it did. I went on the hike this morning in SF and it was awesome. We started at the Ferry Building and made our way up telegraph hill, stairs and all, and then continued up Russian Hill, and ended at the Grace Cathedral in Nob Hill. 

There were times when my legs were burning and I was contemplating giving up. I would pull out my phone and stare at the Lyft app trying to decide if I wanted to hang in there or get the hell outta there. I'm glad I finished the hike because it was a really good workout... I'm sure I'll be sore tomorrow. Each time I thought I couldn't go any further, it would be just about time to stop for Yoga. The Yoga poses stretched out my muscles and made it so I could continue on the next portion of the hike. 

I will definitely be doing this again... Thanks Groupon, and Thanks Hiking Yoga!
author: Samantha L.

description:
The company didn't contact me so I called them and this time someone picked up.  I think it's the admin?  She apologized that I didn't get the email and said she was the one that forgot to cancel the hike that day since the instructor was the one that told her in advance that he won't be available that day.

She extended my perkville coupon for another month and said I could bring a friend for free if I want to as an apology gesture.  I'm still a little skeptical but will give them another chance.
author: Yue L.

description:
My friend and I were in SF for a long weekend and wanted a unique way to explore and see the sights of the city. We saw this on Groupon, were intrigued and bought tickets. Little did we know how much of a workout this was actually going to be. Our guide, Christiane, was great and very friendly! We met at the clock tower at the ferry building and started our 1.5 hour journey promptly at 10am. She took us up 4 very steep hills and stair climbs all of which led up to beautiful views and some yoga! The hills make you breathe heavy but you soon feel relaxed and as calm as ever when the guide leads you through the yoga poses. The journey comes to an end at Coit Tower where you enjoy a longer (and a bit harder) yoga session. This last session leaves you feeling rejuvenated and peaceful! 

Overall, this was a fantastic experience, especially for the Groupon price of $10. I would definitely do it again and recommend it to anyone I know that is traveling to SF!
author: Katelyn M.

description:
Oh Groupon, how do I love thee?  A LOT.

I ran into Hiking Yoga a while back and I just wasn't sure about it.  But then I ran, or rather, hiked into it again on Groupon and I was sold.  For $10 I could try it out.

Signing Up for a Class:  Their online system I found both simple and difficult.  I liked that you could clearly see the options and make sure of your class.  But . . . I didn't like how I didn't know how to pay with my Groupon (or at least I just didn't, but emailed - they were very nice in helping me) or how I couldn't sign up for my husband as well (I'm sure they have their reasons).

The Hike: We signed up for the Los Gatos hike this last weekend.  Again, I guess I just didn't see it, or where it said, "Four Mile Hike" or "Steep Areas" or "Rocky".  But . . . maybe I'm just BLIND.  The first hill is pretty killer and it continues to be steep in places.  There isn't a lot of shade, so seriously bring sunscreen, water, and possibly a hat.  It's rocky, so watch you step.  On the way down, be careful of slipping.  With all that said about the problems, I still enjoyed the hike part (I just need to get in better shape).  I want to try the hike in Woodside next.

The yoga part was nice and so was our instructor, Lisa.  She made sure what levels we were at, if there were any injuries,  included some new moves and I loved the couples moves.  Now my husband and I can incorporate these into our yoga together.  I felt like a bit of a silly hippie doing some of the moves in front of some uber macho bikers, but it was all worth it.

Overall, it was a great experience and I'm looking forward to enjoying my next yoga hike.
author: Sabrina A.

description:
I found Hiking Yoga through a Google search and I went with absolutely no expectations. I knew I loved yoga and I knew I loved hiking. Let's just say that I was pleasantly surprised. 
 
As for the hiking part it was more of a challenge than I thought it would be,
Christiane took us through some beautiful gardens and locations we wouldn't have visited otherwise. The hike was challenging enough get our blood pumping and our heartbeat racing. The yoga was excellent as well, it contained 4 strategic stops along the hike to stretch out your muscles and take in the excellent scenery.
author: Tanner M.

description:
They used to be great - a super fun / different way to get some fresh air & exercise.  I had described hiking yoga as the chocolate + peanut butter of exercise.  

1 star -  last hike teacher no showed.  No call / text / email to let us know.  Extra bad because I had gathered a group to sign up - I would not have recommended hiking yoga if I thought teacher no-show was possible.  

Worse - I've called / emailed several times & no one from Hiking Yoga will respond. Super shady.  Terrible business practice.  Responding to customers is the least they should do.  I know $20 isn't a huge sum - it's more the principle.
author: Whit L.

description:
I did a hike with Emily this past Saturday and she was great!  She's super fit and easy to follow but keeps it challenging.  We met in front of the Ferry Building and some people were late because they couldn't find parking, but Emily made up for it by taking us on a good hike and fit in three yoga sessions - stretching, balancing and partner yoga (in that order).  We ended up at Grace Cathedral, which was so pretty!  

We had five (5) people on our hike, including myself, which was perfect.  I hope this week's class is not any bigger.  I purchased two hikes off Groupon, which was $18 or $20.  I can't wait for this Saturday's session and to buy more hikes off Groupon.  I missed the last deal!  =(
author: Chris L.

description:
Did this yoga hike with a few girlfriends when we were in town visiting and we LOVED it. It's a perfect way to see the various neighborhoods of SF and to sneak in a quick but effective workout. 

The yoga hike started at the Port of San Francisco and ended at North Beach, totaling approx. 3 miles and lasting 90 minutes. It included lots of climbing hills and stairs, with 4 stops for yoga at beautiful and iconic vista points in the city. I was kind of scared to reveal my yoga ineptness but the sessions were capped at an intimate 10-15 people with mostly 20s & 30s somethings at all levels of fitness. The yoga poses ranged from beginner to intermediate levels, and the hike was not that physically demanding but will definitely get you sweating!  

So put on some comfy shoes, slip into those cute yoga pants, bring a bottle of water, and get ready for a nice, enjoyable, and fun morning yoga hike!
author: Annie N.

description:
Fraud company,  beware! 
Love to get money and do nothing. 

Thank you for the worst experience with the prepaid tours,  which I have bought so far.  You are the worst.
My friends and me bought a hiking yoga class for today 6/14/15 at 10 am in SF. 
The instructor just did not show up at least for the place where 10 people had been waiting for him. We had been waiting for the instructor for half an hour in front of the ferry building.  Nobody notified us that class was cancelled. We called,  sent e-mail several times ,  and nobody was answering.
author: Anna B.

description: My cousin and I went on the SF hike. It was challenging but fun. We want to try the other hikes!
author: Ms. S.

description:
You know you are out of shape when...

... you buy a Hiking Yoga Groupon, read that it is a strenuous hike, resolve to get in better shape before going on the hike, and then realize your Groupon is about to expire.*
... you meet at the Ferry Building for your yoga hike but secretly hope no one will show up so can go to Hogs Island for happy hour instead.
... your ambivalence about yoga evolves into serious love when you realize that is the only time you can catch your breath on this fast paced urban hike.
... you start to hate every pretty staircase in North Beach and Russian Hill because you have to climb ALL of them.
... you are eating the dust of the pregnant lady on the hike.

(The feeling afterwards and the view from Coit Tower made the public shaming all worthwhile though.)

*Luckily Hiking Yoga extended the expiration date and added extra sessions.  Classy!
author: Amy C.

description:
Hiking Yoga is amazing. I bought the two for one groupon deal and was so happy to be introduced to this!

This past weekend I did the Los Gatos hike at Lexington Reservoir. Eric Kipp, the owner was our instructor, which was cool. It was fun hearing about his past and how the company was started. 

The hike was about 3.13 miles. I know that because after Eric sent a recap of the hike from his iphone to our email. We did it in exactly 90 minutes and burned 730 calories! what a workout. I am still a little sore...three days later!

okay this concept is amazing. I love to hike and i love yoga...although I havent done yoga in a while, but that didnt matter! It is a perfect combo

It is about 60 minutes of hiking and 30 of yoga! I cant tell you how freakin amazing I felt afterwards! I felt so relaxed, refreshed, and happy! I think I am going to put this in my normal workout regimen! I cant wait to try the other locations...woodside and SF!!

You must try this..it was so fun...met some cool people and really enjoyed myself!
author: Brittany G.

description:
This is a long and overdue review (sorry for the length).

I believe Hiking Yoga is executing a great plan. Read their website or other reviews for a description.

While Hiking Yoga say they cater to all fitness levels, they don't. They cater to really active people, and it left inactive people to be clumped in the back as the group breaks up and there is no longer a social atmosphere, rather a catch-up atmosphere. 

I am definitely not as active as other hikers that participated on the hike, and I was always upfront about that. I was reassured that I would have a great time, and the hike caters to everyone. There were 2-3 leaders in our group. One of the other groups was cancelled, so they merged 2 groups together.

I felt really bad for the last lady in the group...she was so behind in the group. One of the group leaders and I waited for her to catch up. He looked distraught waiting for her.  When she finally reached him, he told her, "I have to catch up with the rest of the group. I am going to leave you here with my friend, who will finish up the hike with you." 
Turns to the friend and says, "I am sorry you came from out of town to hang out, but can you help with this?" The friend obliged, the lady looked pissed, and I didn't blame her.  When we finally reached back to the Ferry Building, the leader was like, "I don't know where my friend and that lady is...I think they are lost. Not sure how I am going to find them."

Honestly, the hiking yoga journey I went on did NOT cater to all activity levels. And shame on the leader who ditched his slower client. Not sure why he HAD to catch up with the front of the group, I asked one of the other hikers if he made a speech or something when he caught up to the group, and she said no, the leader was just talking about the rest of his day plans. 

Lame. I will walk through the city on my own! 

Did make a cool contact in the group that day.
author: Anisha G.

description:
I absolutely enjoyed my hiking yoga experience. Its an intense workout, so don't go thinking it'd be a relaxing touristy hike. Nope, you will work your butt off for that view. The workout starts out with a short walk, then a few yoga poses, followed by further hikes up really steep hills. Like steep hills with a crazy incline. Don't despair though, you'll thank yourself once you get to the top because you would have reached an SF gem with the most amazing view of the city. 

Its a good way to get to know the city, meet new work out friends and thank yourself for kicking ass on a tough workout.
author: Lea F.

description: Very cool way to hike and do yoga at the same time. Plus you get to see some hidden spots in SF. Wesleigh you were awesome!
author: Karim F.

description:
I blindly bought a 10 pass package, and I'm so glad I did. I did my first hiking yoga class on Saturday from the Embarcadero with Wesleigh and it was the absolute best!  As someone who isn't a huge yoga fan (because I'm not flexible and not good at it), it was very enjoyable because the yoga was used as a "meditation/catch your breath after climbing a mountain of a hill" moment!

I am so excited to add this to my Saturday schedule.
author: Vanessa L.

description:
Oh HIKING YOGA, how do I love thee? Let me count the ways!

1. Eric - you know how awesome Barney Stinson is? Well, Eric is of that caliber. And he's witty and helps us burn 1000 calories at heavenly local hidden gems. He's really tall so totally hard to miss, and he'll carry your purses & provide aqua for you. Again, awesome!

2. Sunset yoga at the Coit tower with views of both the golden gate and bay bridges. San Diego and Los Angeles locations somehow couldn't compare to SF. Maybe I simply just love the weather that whisks away all my gnarly sweating. 

3. How much does skinny hurt? like a beeshhh!! Fitness levels: it's intense. My legs are not meant for SF hills. But if you want a realllllllllllly good and fun workout, this is sooooo it! 

4. How freaking good you feel afterwards!!! 

5, 6, 7, 8 , 9 oh gosh, too many reasons to love. Find your own!
author: Missie L.

description:
Christiane was our leader, she waited for everyone to arrive and contacted those who were running late to let them know how they could meet up with her. The group was either young (college age or slightly beyond), or baby boomers. Christiane advised us that we would be walking about 3 miles an hour for 90 minutes, with some uphill for cardio, 4 stops for yoga ending up at the Campanile for a final stretch. 

This hike is not for someone who does not exercise regularly - the hills are challenging at the 3.0 mph pace. Unlike one of the negative Yelp reviews from 2011, Christiane did circle back, look back, wave, and had people looking out for the ones who were slower (moi). I got so overheated that I had to stop a couple of times going up hill, but didn't want to get left behind - even though I knew my way back (home) but I wanted to hang in there.

While we didn't see Maybecks and Morgans as promised in the PR hype on the website, the walk was pleasant, we saw some views, she warned us that some of the views would be occluded by fog and they were. 

The people in our group were very pleasant - and it was easy to talk to each other. A nice hiking yoga experience - but you need to be able to do the cardio and the yoga moves. I opted out of some of them because some of the stretches and poses could have introduced new injuries as I only do restorative yoga poses. You just have to know your limits and know what not to try if you've never done yoga before - you can really injure yourself as a yoga novice. 

There is no judgment when you can't keep up or do the yoga poses. Christiane encourages you to do what you can and to have fun along with exercising.

Truthfully though, for my fitness level, I wouldn't go again, but I bought two hikes and have to take the second before the end of October, so I will go again knowing what the challenges are, and opt out as I need to, or I will share my hike with someone who is able to participate more fully in the experience. I met a very nice woman who walked my pace so that was a bonus - we chatted as we hiked.

Christiane's  fitness and energy is inspiring. 

Recommend that a different level of hiking yoga be offered for people who are not as fit -- on level ground instead of the climbing which puts a lot of stress on knees (that last climb up the stairs to Cedar - I think - was a killer); and was for me almost too much cardio-wise.
author: Mamie L.

description:
I regretting signing up for something so early on a Sunday morning, but I am so glad we did.  We used the Groupon, but are gonna definitely come back for more and maybe purchase one of the package deals.

Eric's awesome!  His Hiking Yoga sessions are a must-do for those wanting a challenging hike/yoga session in the urban-y outdoors.  Luckily, we hiked on a rare beautiful, sunny San Francisco morning.  Eric was easy to spot in front of the Ferry Building (tall guy wearing a huge hiking backpack).  The group (usually capped at 15 people) was a good mix of newcomers and usuals/veteran yoga hikers, and both Eric and the usuals did a great job of cultivating the group dynamic and making everyone feel welcome.  I'm at the beginning fitness level and these yoga hikes seem to accommodate all levels (Eric maintained a fast pace for the intermediate to advanced hikers, but even at the back of the pack, I was still able to see far enough ahead to know where to go).  He definitely utilizes those steep San Francisco uphills.

Eric brings the yoga mats so you don't have to.  The last yoga session we did that Sunday was partner yoga, which is so fun that you may even get a bit of a laugh out of it.  =)  The shining sun and light breeze made the perfect backdrop to the close of our last yoga session at Coit Tower.

Who knew you could explore San Francisco (and get to know it's steep uphills so well) and get in such a great workout along the way?  Eric certainly puts his tour guide experience to great use.  I can't wait until Eric brings his yoga hikes to the South Bay!
author: Shawn F.

description:
Hannah S: Get today's Groupon! Yevi A. and I signed up for a 9am Yoga Hike on Sunday!

Me: 9am? Sunday? Yoga hike? What ARE you smoking and can I have some?

I barely made it to the Ferry Building on time, but I am SO glad that I did! This was such a fun way to start a random Sunday. I am not a yoga person, and I have to say that I found some of the yoga poses to be pretty challenging - and that's a good thing! We hit some big hills on our hike through North Beach to Coit Tower, and I was definitely feeling the burn. There's a great mix of exploring a new neighborhood, gorgeous views, low impact cardio, stretching, and yoga. 

Eric is awesome, and I am hoping to do one of the Dinner Hikes sometime soon! As Hannah S. said, this would be a GREAT activity to do with an out of town visitor, or just to get to know your own city a bit better.

Value: 4 stars
Service: 5 stars
Workout: 5 stars
author: Shannon B.

description:
I did my first hike with Wesleigh from the Ferry Building in San Francisco on 9/9/12.  Throughly enjoyed myself.  Loved the urban hike as there are plenty of hills and stairs to challenge one self.  The yoga was rather light overall, but as she mentioned you are wearing shoes, on uneven surfaces, etc. so you will not get the same as a studio workout.  

I've purchased a package of 3, so I will certainly be back!
author: Teri X.

description:
I did a couple of hikes at the Wunderlich Park. it was a great experience. 
I did not know the park before these classes, and I think it was the best place to do it, because you are all the time under very tall trees and under the shade. 

The yoga part was very good. The feeling of being on the wood while doing it was amazing. 
The only part that was not that perfect was the dodging of hos manure along the trails. 

I highly recommend the experience, and I'll will definitely do it again soon.
author: Isa J.

description: This is a great work out!!! The views are absolutely beautiful and it was great chatting with others along the way as well. Highly recommend :)
author: Cynthia G.

description: I went on a Saturday hike to Coit Tower and it was such a great experience. The instructor, Christiane, brought really positive energy to the activity and provided helpful alignment adjustments during the yoga stops. Being new to SF, I loved seeing the city from new angles and chatting with other hikers. It's definitely a workout - you take the hills at a pretty brisk pace - but you get to catch your breath while enjoying amazing views.
author: Esther C.

description:
I took the Yoga Hiking class with Christiane in San Francisco. It is a good workout with a lot of climbing up and down stairs and the streets. If you are not looking to do a little cardio this is not for you. We stopped 4 times during the hike to do a few yoga moves. Christiane is helpful and adjusted us. 

This is a great way to visit neighborhoods off of the beaten path and to see beautiful views of the bay. It was a little challenging to do yoga in sneakers and on uneven pavement but it was fun. We ended our yoga hike at Coit Tower after an hour and a half and Christiane left us and we had to find our way back to the Ferry Building which was easy but a little strange.

All in all, I would recommend this yoga hike!
author: Patti W.

description:
Names don't get more self-explanatory than Hiking Yoga, so definitely give it a try if you like fast-paced cardio but can also appreciate a little tree-pose zen.

Go for:
-Awesome trails with amazing views
-Unconventional exercise
-Kick-ass workout that might make your gluteus maximus feel a little less maximus
-That "good soreness" afterward that makes you feel totally accomplished (probably as you gorge on post-workout junk food, like I usually do)
-A reminder that the Bay Area is amazing!!!

Get:
-Christiane or Emily for instructors--both are fab

Skip:
-Going solo. When we yoga'ed at Grace Cathedral, some moves involved some pretty touchy-feely buddy action. Good thing I brought a friend (thanks, Gay Husband).
-Bringing anything you don't absolutely need (I left my phone behind on purpose. Take that, modern civ!)
-Some of the yoga moves, which were either a little uncomfortable or just awkward to do after intense-ish cardio. Couldn't quite find my center when my heart was going 160 rpm

Both the Berkeley & SF trails are awesome. Head's up: You may not end up exactly where you started, so plan accordingly as far as metering/parking, etc.
author: Cindy Q.

description:
If you're looking to get your butt off the couch and have some fun, Hiking Yoga is a great way to get out and get your sweaty on. A while ago, I did the hike in San Francisco that meets at the Ferry Building, and more recently, I went on the hike in Berkeley with Christiane - she's great!
        
Things I like about Hiking Yoga:

The pace - This isn't a stroll in the park. You definitely get your heart rate going, and depending on how in shape (or not) you are, you might be huffing and puffing. (I found myself jogging and scurrying to keep up here and there.) Sweating is unavoidable. And the stairs. Oh my god, the stairs.

The yoga - There were 4 yoga stations or breaks during the Berkeley hike. They started off nice and easy, but got progressively more challenging. By the third yoga station, my legs and core were definitely working to hold the poses. I have terrible balance and would occasionally fall out of some of the poses, but I found Christiane to be super helpful and encouraging. She spent time helping each person in the class, making adjustments to his/her form.

The instructors - Christiane was so nice! She was great to talk to, and her soothing voice seems to have been made for teaching yoga. It really helped me focus and center myself at each station. Plus, she was great at spending time with everyone in the class both while we were doing yoga and hiking - she also did a good job of making sure the group didn't straggle too far apart during the hike.

The views - On both of the hikes that I've been on, I really appreciated the routes we took and all of the scenery along the way. It's easy to go through everyday life without really enjoying your surroundings, and Hiking Yoga gives you the chance to take it all in. I live in San Francisco and went to college in Berkeley, and during the hikes, we visited areas of both that I had previously never seen or spent much time in.

The only drawback/consideration:

Parking - If you park in a metered spot, you may have to cut out early if the class runs over the allotted 90 minutes. Which means you'll have to miss some of the yoga at the last station. Boo.
author: Stephanie K.

description: Wow ... awesome Sunday morning tour of the Berkeley hills.   Crazy stairs through the neighborhood resulted in a really good hike,  balanced with some courtyard yoga amid the roses and jasmine.   Would definitely do the tour again.
author: Jo Ann P.

description:
I've done two yoga hikes - one in Berkeley and one in San Francisco, and they were both great. Before I did it, I thought it would be in the woods, like actual hiking, but it's more just walking (quite vigorously, however) in neighborhoods. The San Francisco one meets at the Ferry Building and goes up around Coit Tower and down the other side, then back up to Coit Tower for the final yoga stop. The Berkeley one meets on the Cal campus and goes up into the neighborhoods north of campus and then loops back through campus for the finish. They both have great scenery, and both leaders that I've had (Laurie in SF and Christiane in Berkeley) were very friendly. Laurie's yoga stops were more involved, even including several partner poses, which I always think is ambitious when you don't know how comfortable people are going to be with touching strangers. Also, what if you have an odd-numbered group? Maybe she just counts and doesn't do partner poses with those groups...anyway, it was cool. The SF one is definitely harder than the Berkeley one. I did it yesterday and my thighs are sore.
I'd definitely go back to either one. I've gone alone both times and it seems like most people do it with a friend, but I've had good conversations with new people both times, so. :)
author: Erin A.

description: Hiking yoga was fantastic! I went with my boyfriend during our visit to SF. It was the perfect blend of getting in a decent workout and also getting to see some of the sites. I would definitely recommend it and would do it again! The leader of the hike was great also!
author: Alison C.

description: My friend & I had a great time at Hiking Yoga this weekend! She is an avid hiker (did the whole AT) and I'm a yoga teacher so it was a great activity to do together. We are both SF locals & it was fun discovering some staircases & little beautiful garden alleys that we wouldn't have found on our own. The yoga was sequenced with hiking in mind, so focused on leg & back work, mainly standing poses. I was a little surprised that the 90-min tour ended at Coit Tower - it was no problem finding our way back to the Ferry Building, but I assumed it would end in the same place that we started. So plan some extra time to get back to your starting place. The hiking pace was pretty quick & I definitely got a good work out - I wouldn't recommend it if you don't like walking up steep hills. Overall a great experience! Thanks Hiking Yoga :)
author: Katie H.

description:
I took my first Hiking Yoga class August 3 in San Francisco with Christiane. We started at the ferry building. In the beginning we were told that if attendees were lagging behind (due to fitness levels) the group would circle back and pick them up so we could all do our yoga stops together. 
I'm a pretty fit person, so I did fine for the first two climbs and yoga stops. Its a bit challenging to do some yoga moves on inclined/uneven pavement, but I managed just fine. Christiane was attentive to the class and walked around adjusting us where necessary. The idea is you get a really vigorous hike in, then stop to recover your breath with some yoga poses. After the second stop I found myself in the back of the pack with a really nice lady who was on her 4th yoga hike. 
The group left the two of us behind. We rounded a corner and saw no one. We called the instructor and left a voice message after walking around Grace Cathedral looking for everyone (we were both under the impression that Grace Cathedral was our third stop). 
Luckily for me my fellow yogi was a laid back soul as well and we had a good laugh about being left behind, then took off to see the Fairmont Hotel. She was a local and I was an out of towner and I think we enjoyed each other's company for our little detour. 
Please note: this is NOT for anyone who is not cardiovascularly fit. This is a good way to see some really interesting neighborhoods in San Francisco (and get a heavy cardio workout in!). Do not expect this to be anything like a regular yoga class. Of course I wasn't able to complete the session so I'm not sure what the last stop is like. 
Would I do it again? Probably not in San Francisco. I might consider it in another city but honestly I'd prefer either a hike in the forest, a walk in a city, or a "typical" yoga class over this hybrid. Glad I tried it and enjoyed the conversation I had during the hike, but it's just overall not for me. I would probably enjoy something like this if we were on a dedicated hiking trail much more.
author: Alysia G.

description:
LA has it's highways and New York has it's subways for getting around.  What many tourists (1/2 of the folks on my Embarcadero route were from out of town)  may not realize is that SF has its STAIRS and steep sets that come at you, one after another!   We burned 853 calories, climbed over 1000 ft for some secret santuaries in SF.

I loved this combination... it's more of a power walk, stair climbing and stretching routine than hiking/yoga per say.   But I can see why calling it walk and stretch isn't as appealing .:-)    Incredibly beautiful and serene paths through streets and back alleys that I'd never traveled on.  I can't wait to try the Coit tower itinerary.  Gregg was a great pacesetter for this and he will have you huffing and puffing but also feeling quite relaxed at the same time.  He was friendly to all, locals and tourists were equally lead, unlike some other outfits where out of towners get the royal treatment and the rest were 2nd class citizens.

Beware though... If you are not interested or able to leap tall staircases, at least 5 flights at a time, skip this and get on a cable car instead.  One twenty something in my group jokingly proclaimed, "FALSE advertising!!! This should have been called run and stairs!"
author: Surai J.

description:
I had such a great time this past Saturday with Christiane in Berkeley. The hike was nice and at parts definitely made you grind your heels and crank it out (e.g. the stairs!) and having yoga interspersed in between the hike made it so that your body was never quite sure what was going to happen next, which I understand helps to burn more cals. 

The hike was scenic and beautiful, and took me to places that I didn't even knew existed in UCB's backyard. 

Loved it. Can't wait for SF.
author: Jenna K.

description:
Hiking Yoga in San Francisco yesterday with Julie Bennett and crew was a blast!
Hard to think of a better way to kick start the weekend than to spend 90 minutes of fast-paced hiking interspersed with yoga poses, with a delightful group of happy, like-minded people. Hard work, but a blast. I'll be back next Saturday.
author: Lottie K.

description:
Definitely more hiking than yoga.

After purchasing a Groupon, I attended 2 Saturday hikes that started at the Ferry Building. And the hiking part was fine: I got to check out some open spaces close to the Embarcadero and Telegraph Hill that I'd never visited before, and the view of Coit Tower was quite spectacular.

The 'yoga,' however, was fairly minimal, and consisted of just 4 mid-hike pit-stops along the way. I would describe it more as gentle stretching: no real 'poses' (mats are not required) and nothing all that challenging or especially meditative. 

Bottom line: if I wanted to do something like this again, I'd probably just go for a walk around the Embarcadero/North Beach on my own, and maybe do a few poses along the way (and not pay for the privilege). But I'm happy I gave it a shot, if only for the knowledge of those hidden grassy gems at the top of the Embarcadero Center.
author: Amanda F.

description: Found some neat spots of the city I never knew about, enjoyed some awesome views and a friendly instructor, mad did some yoga. All together, a great experience as long as the weather is good. If you aren't in at least average shape, the hike up some SF hills might be challenging. The yoga was pretty basic. Christiane was a great leader/instructor.
author: Colin W.

description:
went here with my fiance using a groupon; prior to this had never heard of hiking yoga. but hey: we like to hike. and we like yoga. so this seemed fitting. 

met under the clock tower at the ferry building at 10 to six on a tuesday evening. met a group of about 6-8 other urbanites, mostly in pairs/ couples, and left promptly. eric is cheerful, encouraging, and full of energy: he'll get you up those hills in such a motivating way, that you may even forget what tough work it is! saw some hidden gems throughout russian hill, north beach, and up to coit tower-- a few streets that were pleasantly tucked away; gorgeous vistas of bay bridge; and yoga atop community parks i never knew existed. 

my definite pros were:
- brisk hiking/ walking + tons of hills. my hamstrings loved it.
- uplifting encouraging attitude, but no pressure- great for newbies
- ratio of 30 min yoga to 60 min hiking is perfect for me. i have a hard time with 60 min yoga classes. yoga style is casual, with a few downward dogs, warriors, and use of benches as props. ended with some partner yoga which was fun!
- mini mats provided
- the rest of the group was so nice!

what i would've liked to know:
- parking in SF can be hard
- yoga in shoes is a weird feeling, but wear lightweight sneakers with good traction and you should be just fine
- dress in dry-wick layers, and consider sunglasses. we broke a bit of a sweat but the sf breeze was helpful.

we'd totally do this again. it was a unique and fun experience. eric sent us a link afterwards of where we went, and it also included a fun fact: we burned over 900 calories in 90 min. for real!?
author: Debora L.

description:
I've done the yoga hikes in Los Gatos, Woodside and San Francisco and loved them all.  This is a really wonderful way to work out because it is so much more than a workout - you get to spend time outdoors in incredibly beautiful places and meet some great people along the way.

I'm a lifelong hiker but new to yoga, and I found both the hiking and the yoga to be challenging, but not overwhelming.  The instructors (Eric & Christiane for my hikes) kept a brisk pace without pushing anyone too hard and handled the varying yoga abilities in the groups with ease.

I would definitely recommend Hiking Yoga to Bay Area locals and visitors alike.  I plan to check out other locations in my own travels - and head back to the nearby hikes as well.
author: Susan C.

description:
Wow, at the time i am writing this review, Hiking Yoga is rated 5 stars based on 105 reviews. That is definitely impressive.

This review is with regards to the hike in Los Gatos. I couldn't find one setup for LG and i'm too lazy to look any deeper or setup a new one so i'm adding this one to SF. 

My wife and I came here thorough Groupon, like many other people have, and we were thoroughly happy with the purchase. The hike was great, and though the yoga was fairly minimal, all in all the experience was fantastic.

There are a few things to note, however. On the website as well as the confirmation email, it said to arrive promptly and that the group would leave on time. Of course, we didn't and we ended up waiting for one last couple who got lost. Lame. That kind of thing irks me to no end.

Also, and this isn't necessarily a bad thing, but the time said 8:30-10am, and the class itself ran almost exactly that long...except when the class ended, we were at the top of the hill that we were hiking! Fortunately we didn't have any plans after that, it's just something to keep in mind if you are scheduling at the LG hike.

I honestly don't think i would go back to hiking yoga without a groupon--my wife and i hike and do yoga for free as it is--but it really is a cool idea and i can see why it is so highly spoken of.
author: Daniel G.

description:
Saw a write-up of Hiking Yoga in a local magazine and thought I would give it a try. I like seeing new parts of the city of San Francisco and I am a yogi. 

I love love love Hiking Yoga and will be doing it again. My teacher Antoinette was a spitfire. She is really fast.  It is a fast pace walk up steep hills with 4 stops to do yoga postures. 

I really liked that the teacher stopped to point out S.F. landmarks and spectacular vistas. I learned some San Fran history. 

Just remember to bring your own water and dress in layers. A mini yoga mat is provided in the portion of the class that involves postures on the ground. 

I can't wait to do this again.
author: Infodiva B.

description:
This is both a great cardio workout and a wonderful way to see the city. It's hard to beat warrior pose looking out over the bay, and it's fun to "wander" (not really the right word, given the fast pace) through new neighbourhoods, feeling a little jealous of the people who live in the beautiful houses there, but mostly just feeling lucky to live in/near (or be visiting) such a gorgeous city. The only downside for me? As it turns out, I think I just don't like yoga (I've tried a few different classes at a few different studios...maybe I just haven't hit my groove yet). The first few "yoga stations" (I think there are 4 over the course of the hike, with the last one being the longest) were fine for me, and didn't involve really difficult poses. But when we got to the last station, the yoga became a little more serious, and I wasn't a huge fan. But the awkward/uncomfortable poses were a small enough part of the whole experience that I'd definitely do it again. (And, I mean, the company's name is "Hiking Yoga," so it's not really reasonable to complain that the workout involves yoga ;) )

I think this would be a great thing to do with friends visiting from out of town (as long as they're up for a work out), and it's definitely a great thing for locals who want to take some time to appreciate their home. I recommend bringing a friend, and having brunch afterward!
author: Gwyneth H.

description: What a way to see the city! I am a local but I still did not know of all the fun stuff we saw on our tour of the city. I brought my sis from out of town and it was wonderful to show her the city without having to think about where I would take her. Perfect printing off point for more adventures in SF.
author: Kim A.

description:
I'd been mildly worried about this course because I've not been exercising enough lately aside from walking my dog a couple miles a day, and that's not exactly strenuous---even with a 90-pound dog! My concern was that I'd be gasping and slowing everyone down.

Anyway, I went to tonight's 5:30 session, with Greg as the instructor. He was fantastic: extremely positive, well-trained, and helpful. And it was a great mix of cardio and yoga, which he was able to adjust to the varying experience and fitness levels of the 12 people who showed up (a few people bailed at the last minute, but the max group size is 16). We saw areas of Russian Hill, Telegraph Hill, and other areas I've never seen in my 13 years here.

Aside from the exercise, the great views, and Greg's expert instruction,  the best part (and one that I absolutely didn't expect) was the high level of social interaction. It was a diverse group, half male and half female, with two couples and a few tourists. But because you're stopping every 10 minutes or so to do the yoga, you invariably get mixed around as you move on to the next stop. Everyone was very friendly, and it reminded me yet again why I have a hard time imagining life anywhere but San Francisco (at least in the US).

And that was true whether I was chatting with the woman visiting from Scotland, a young gay couple, a woman who happens to live 2 blocks from me, or anyone else. This is a special area that is home to and attracts many great people, and this was a special experience. I usually don't sound so sappy, but this course was so much better than I'd expected! Thanks Greg! Hope to see you again soon!

Paul
author: Buzz B.

description:
Hiking and Yoga are two of my passions in life - at least for the year 2011 - so when I found this deal, I knew for certain that God heard my prayers.  The first one that I went to was headed by Elena and then the 2nd one was last weekend and headed by Eric.  Both of them are very good and very knowledgeable.  There is always a big group on both times that I went and I always end up making new friends each time.  The views along St Joseph's Trail in Los Gatos is just wonderful...makes me always grateful that I'm alive! 

2nd time I went I was panting a little bit trying to catch up with Eric.  He is over 6feet tall so he has giant strides.  I am a midget at 5'3 woman but I'm a power hiker so I did get a very good workout on a Sunday morning.  I also want to do the one in Woodside and San Francisco...one of these days.

And also, I did the 14-day Detox Cleanse with Eric and Caley.  It was such a wonderful program.  They were very supportive of us virtually.  Everyday during the cleanse, they would send us videos and they even created a custom FB page for us so we could all support each other.  That program really jump-started my metabolism.  Because of that, I feel like I am on the right track with my health.  I learned so much about food and how I can use it to explore your full potential.  The first 3 days were the hardest but after that, I felt better, more energized and healthier.  Everybody should do that program - you will learn a lot of things about yourself.
author: Sharon C.

description:
Summary: Get out of the office/gym and into nature, interact with friends and make new ones, plus cardio and basic yoga.  Woodside is a great hike, and Eric is a friendly and knowledgeable instructor!

I saw the 2-for-1 deal on Groupon and invited another couple to join me and the hubby for a try.  We'd only ever done yoga as part of the P90X regime (it's hard!), but we enjoy hiking and thought it would be a great idea to get together and get out of the house.

Before the hike, Eric who's the founder and our designated instructor sent us a email to confirm the time and location.  We were initially concerned about cancellation because we had booked several months in advance, but it turns out that we worried for nothing.  We also wondered about yoga mats and whether we would mind grimy used ones, but it's actually not needed (for the tour we went on, at least).

As for the hike, it was the four of us joined by another couple, also first-timers.  Eric chatted with us about his background, sports, and fitness while we waited for the appointed time to begin.  He is friendly and knowledgeable, and it certainly doesn't hurt that he is tall and incredibly fit.  We started out with an easy hike and warm-up yoga at the first station (a larger area along the trail), then alternated between stretches of hiking and yoga at different stations.  Eric was very good about explaining the different positions, building up on difficulty and offering alternatives, and gently correcting incorrect postures.  My favorite was the couples' and group yoga at the last station.  There were 4 total, and the whole hike lasted 2 hours, which was half an hour more than we paid for.  I had a very positive experience and would definitely recommend Hiking Yoga to friends.

Pros:
- Great for yoga newbies.  It's OK to tip over laughing, and Eric is very encouraging.
- Great for get togethers.  Think yoga in the morning, lunch, then shopping.  Or just to get the hubby off the couch.
- Great if you like nature and variety.  I'm not sure my quads would hold up doing yoga for an hour straight, so this is perfect for me.

Cons:
- I wonder what happens when it rains?
- If you walk slow then you might miss some yoga at every station.
author: Jeannette K.

description: I read about Hiking Yoga in the SF Chronicle and signed up for a Saturday class during my recent visit to San Francisco. After a healthy breakfast at the Ferry Building Farmer's Market, I joined the group for a fast-paced hike up and down the hilly streets of SF. What a workout! I loved the "yoga breaks" at various scenic landmarks and especially enjoyed the final meditation beneath beautiful Coit Tower. My only complaint is that the leader showed up a bit late, but she was able to call one of the participants in advance who warned us. Overall, a very positive experience - I will do it again next time I'm in town!
author: Patty N.

description:
I took this class through a Groupon offer that I had.  I took a weeknight class with Greg and a weekend morning class with Eka (both starting at Embarcadero).

Both classes were pretty awesome and followed roughly the same path through the Financial District to Chinatown to Russian Hill to Telegraph Hill.  They alternate between sections of hike and then yoga which allows you to rest for a minute.

Each class/instructor had its unique points of awesomeness: I really like that Greg encouraged everyone to get to know the others on the hike (without sacrificing the yoga experience) and we did some really cool stretches using parts of our environment such as park benches.  Eka really got into my brain more and helped to create an experience of awesome self-awareness and intense renewal.  Both were very well trained and led awesome experiences where I got to see the city in a different light!

I would definitely return and recommend that everyone tries it out!
author: Chad P.

description: I had never done Yoga before so I was a little nervous but ended up having an awesome time. Wesley took us through these crazy beautiful paths you'd never find yourself in the city. The yoga was more relaxing than difficult. Some other reviews said the hiking is strenuous but I disagree (unless you're not used to walking hills in the city) It's a great way to start the weekend.
author: Aaron H.

description:
Two hours of intense hiking with challenging yet relaxing yoga.

Went to my first session in Berkeley with Sarah. She is really nice and really seems to have mastered yoga. Found out that she just had a baby and she looks great! Another testament on the wonders of what hiking and yoga can do for your body. 

Our group was 6 ladies (including the instructor). Everyone was in pretty good shape so we were moving briskly the whole time. We climbed pretty high in elevation and got to enjoy some great views of the bay. This is a great way to work out and get some fresh air. 

I highly recommend giving this place a try if you love yoga and the great outdoors!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
I did the LA hike in Griffith Park.  It was well organized with awesome views and at just the right level.  The leader was enthusiastic and great.  I wished it could have gone on longer.

It would be nice to alternate hiking routes to keep us coming back for more.
author: Lori L.

description: WOW! What a blast that was! I enjoyed a wonderful hike and yoga practice with Emily today. :) We explored the magical Wunderlich Park in Woodside. I got a great workout during our hike, as Emily lead the way with her joyful energy. Stopping along the way at various spots to stretch and try poses was refreshing and peaceful. I felt so great when we were through. I look forward to another Hiking Yoga adventure with Emily. She ROCKS. :)
author: Amy Grace C.

description:
The Woodside hike with Emily was great! I found out about it from Groupon. 

It was a good heart-pumping and spacious workout for me with moderate uphills and relaxing yoga poses and breaths intermixed. 

I highly recommend it and plan to do the Los Gatos hike in a couple weeks.
author: Karla L.

description:
I was jumping with excitement when I saw this on groupon a couple months back!!! WHAT A STEAL two classes for $20, normally it is $20 for one class. I love hiking already now with yoga get out of here. I became the spokes person for this deal and made all my girlfriends buy it and in turn now I have company for the class and referral credit on groupon SWEET PEACHES. win win. 

We signed up for the Berkeley location as our first class we had about six girls a nice small group. Your heart rates actually gets pumped pretty high dont let it fool you. I love how we get to do yoga stretches in between the hike. My fav was the yoga stretches at the end of the class it felt so calming and refreshing. She provides the mat so dont have to fuss over you bringing one along. You will get to see parts of Berkeley where I didn't even know it existed. Overall I HIGHLY recommend this class if you would like a good workout with great views of the cities. Would do this class on a weekly bases if I had the money and time. 

I will be signing up for the San Francisco location for my next class I can't wait to explore the city. TILL THEN keep on munching!!
author: Rosaline C.

description: I've been to Hiking Yoga in SF almost a dozen times with various friends, and it never feels old or dated. The views are spectacular, the teachers friendly, calming, and supportive, and the hikes are challenging in a good way. I have brought almost every close friend with me at one point, and everyone adores the SF hikes. I did the Berkeley hike once; the route is not as breathtaking as SF.
author: SiliconValleyShoeGirl L.

description:
Hiking + Yoga = Happiness

Just did my second Hiking Yoga trip this weekend at their Woodside: Wunderlich Park location. It's so, so lovely with mostly shaded trails through a forest of serene redwoods and ravines. It's a perfect place for hiking yoga if you're a nature lover! In two hours we hiked about 3 miles, periodically stopping (about 3-4 times) for some yoga stretching, (no previous experience in yoga necessary, btw).

Eric Kipp, the instructor was awesome. My first time, I hopped in about 15 minutes late and was fearful that he would be annoyed, but he was actually very inviting and told me to jump right in, correcting my postures and even took the time to get to know me through some of the hike. The group, too, had a good vibe which made for perfect opportunities for lazy conversation.

I'd definitely recommend this for those of any skill level. There is a 10-15 minute trek on an adequate incline which is tough enough for a challenge, yet short enough not to wear you out for the rest of the hike. Being with the group definitely pulled me through this part. And even if you have to go considerably slower than the rest, Eric puts no pressure on you to keep up. You're definitely allowed to set your own pace and catch up at the next yoga stop.

Definitely looking forward to the SF & Berkeley locations!

Additional Pros:
- After the hike, the instructor emails a Runkeeper link, which tracks the trail route, miles hiked, calories burned, etc.
- Perkville.com allows you to refer friends which can get you a free hike, (~4 ppl)
author: May N.

description:
I saw hiking yoga on groupon one day and decided it would be an interesting new experience, so I purchased. Today, I went on my first excursion in Woodside at Wunderlich Park and it was truly enjoyable.

There were only four of us in the group, which was great since it was my first time participating. Total time was about an hour and 40 minutes, a great, rejuvenating workout. 

Hiking at Wunderlich was like taking a staycation. The place is absolutely gorgeous, alive with enormous Redwoods, wildlife and serenity. I honestly felt like I was hiking in Big Sur. The trails weren't crowded at all, which was a pleasant surprise considering it was a beautiful fall day and the weekend. The trail we took was challenging but enjoyable, and the view from the top (at various points) was stunning.

As for our instructor, Emily, I can't say enough good things. She was completely personable and knowledgeable, and she has this wonderful positive presence--a great person to spend your Sunday morning hiking with!

In addition to the natural beauty and multiple trails, the park has an added little bonus--at the top of the parking area, there's a beautiful restored stable, full of equally beautiful horses, that you can walk through and enjoy. Which we did, very much.

If you want a great workout in beautiful surroundings, I'd highly recommend taking your yoga hike in Woodside.
author: jessy l.

description:
Went for the first time after buying a Groupon today. It was amazing and definitely a workout, my legs/feet were definitely in pain after the day was over.

Greg was awesome and very nice. He was easy to follow and kept an awesome pace. We started at the ferry bdg and immediately went up and down throughout the Embarcadero bdgs (1-4). Then we hiked over North Beach up to Russian Hill. At that point we were given the choice between Grace Cathedral and Coit Tower, so we chose Coit Tower and ended the hike there.

The yoga portions were perfectly placed and all areas had the best views of the city. I am definitely excited for my second class (hopefully next week).

After we ended at Coit Tower, Greg was really great about making sure we were good to go and then walked whoever needed to back to the ferry bdg. Definitely a great start to a Saturday morning.
author: Jung-Ah Y.

description:
Greg was a fantastic hiking yoga tour guide/instructor.  I have taken yoga classes before, as well as a previous hiking yoga class; however, Greg was definitely a favorite.  He was very knowledgeable and continuously reminded us all to be aware of and connect to our breath.
His yoga pauses, through the hike were perfectly placed and well timed.  They were also often enough that I really felt I was doing both, and not just hiking with a stretch in the beginning and end.
This is a lovely way to learn the city, or to find something new.  Explore and connect with your breath and your city simultaneously.
author: Laralynne B.

description:
Hiking Yoga was amazing--a great combination of exercises. It's a nice change to work out in the outdoors-- taking in the city, both its green natural spaces and the vibrant street life of neighborhoods like North Beach and Russian Hill. 

I walk all over in the city on my own but the Hiking Yoga instructor set a vigorous pace that got my heart pumping. Teacher Jennifer Minnetti was fantastic at providing condensed and effective yoga instruction at the top of vistas we'd climbed. It was like interval training, with the intense cardio of hill and stair climbing and then the grounding, strengthening, stretching benefits of the yoga practice. I would highly recommend this for anyone who enjoys walking and yoga and wants to mix it up from their usual routine.
author: SfinS F.

description:
The concept sounded great to me - Hiking + Yoga, two things I already really enjoy, but the experience was even better than expected.  I did the Embarcadero hike with Eka and it was a wonderful way to spend a Sunday morning.  He pushed us to experience everything around us in a joyful and encouraging way.

If you have hesitations, stop worrying, and go for it.  The hiking sections are challenging, but not exhausting, and the yoga style is ideal for anyone, even beginners.  

Have fun.
author: Kelly T.

description: Participating in the yoga hike with the personable Christiane last week was utterly enjoyable. I got a great work out, saw places in San Francisco I was unfamiliar with, and met some cool out of towners from our group. I look forward to my next session with much excitement.
author: Darlene C.

description:
31 5 star reviews?  I was immediately suspicious.  Nothing can be that good, not even Cyrus, which IS that good, yet only gets 4 stars.

I found Hiking Yoga while looking for a group activity in SF that didn't require a membership like Urban Tree House or whatever that place is called, or the Outdoor Adventure Club, which looks cool but is a little out of my budget.

I love hiking. I love finding hidden spots in SF. I don't do yoga often, though I have been doing the Dailey Method intermittently. Still, what's not to love about a hiking/yoga combo?

As it turns out, nothing.  It is awesome.  I highly recommend it for locals who don't know about the garage that looks like a castle in North Beach, or about any number of parklets sprinkled down alleyways or up narrow stairs.  I also can't think of a better way for someone from out of town to get a true SF experience, not to mention phenomenal views.

I joined the Hiking + Yoga + Dinner series kickoff for Cinco de Mayo.  After our 4 mile power walk with yoga breaks from the Ferry Building up Vallejo stairs through North Beach and up to Coit Tower, we then strolled down to Union St. to find our group's table ready and waiting at Don Pistos (which was fantastic and deserves its own review).

While the "we've burned 1000 calories" is a bit of hyperbole, the workout was sufficient.  Yesterday would normally be a run day for me, but walking up hills and holding yoga poses worked different muscles, so yay for cross training.

It is easy to get in touch with your inner yogi in a nice, enclosed studio.  Try centering when doing the downward dog in front of tourists. I think there is something to be learned here about getting over being so concerned about what other people think.  I don't know if that's a part of yoga, generally, but certainly is in this class.

Highly recommended.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Last Saturday, we did the Berkeley hike with Christiane.  My friend bought a Groupon for me and I didn't look up the Yelp reviews prior to the hike.  This is definitely a HIKE with a little bit of yoga thrown in.  Don't get me wrong, I loved it, but it is not for the faint of heart.  It was a pretty hot morning and the sun was beating down on us while we power walked and stopped four times to move through our yoga poses.  According to my GPS pedometer, we walked a little over 3-1/2 miles in 90 minutes.  The pace is VERY fast.  If you thought this was going to be a little walking through a pretty park and mostly yoga, you would be very wrong.  And by you, I mean me.  Other than making sure you have a towel for the dripping sweat and plenty of water, I would also suggest parking somewhere other than 90 minute or two hour meters.  The hike went a tiny bit long and we had to leave early to get back to the car to avoid a ticket.  So BART in or take the time to find neighborhood street parking (or find a lot with longer term parking).  After a hike like that, you don't want to miss out on the final delicious stretch and centering around the peaceful water fountain.

Side note from my second attempt to do hiking yoga:  If you are going to be late, don't bother showing up.  My BART train was delayed and I should have been only a few minutes behind the group.  The poor girl apparently doesn't know her lefts from her rights and told me to meet them in the wrong spot.  I was practically running to find them, only to determine later that I was headed in the wrong direction.  It was frustrating and I was never offered a make-up date.
author: Lori M.

description:
I was visiting friends in the South Bay and one of my friends suggested that we sign up for a hiking yoga excursion (she had previously attended some of these classes).  We signed up for the hike in Los Gatos (around the Reservoir area) and it was AWESOME!!

Elena is a terrific instructor and I really like her method of breaking up the hike with yoga throughout.  Especially since the hike in Los Gatos is fairly steep uphill in the beginning, it helps to break it up a little bit.  At the peak of the hike, we took a break to do an extended yoga session and then enjoyed the beautiful view for a little bit, before making our way back down the mountains.

I had a great time with my friends and I recommend Hiking Yoga for anyone who likes outdoors, hiking and yoga!  =)
author: Diana N.

description: Wesleigh is awesome! She led us on a really fun hike through the city - it was a beautiful day and we got a great workout on the many hills in SF :) The yoga is interspersed throughout various stops on the hike and the poses were really well chosen to warm up and strengthen our hiking muscles. The group was also great - lots of interesting people that I enjoyed getting to know. I will definitely do this again!
author: Kaitlin Y.

description: This wasn't what I was expecting, but it was super awesome.  We hiked at a super fast past through the city, stopping at pretty parks to do yoga.  I had one of the most fun work out experiences of my life, and everyone was super friendly!  Can't wait to go again. :)
author: Tasha D.

description:
What a GREAT way to spend an evening.  This really is an excellent workout with some of the most astounding views of our lovely city. The route we took last night went around telegraph hill and north beach. The hike can be pretty intense for those who are not used to a ton of cardio (moi), but every few hills you climb, there is a gentle session of yoga stretches and a chance to catch up and reconnect with the body and breathe. We ended the session near Coit tower with some partner yoga (the tourists got a kick out of that but whateverm everyone was laughing and had a good time). Most people come with a group of friends, but if you go solo I will guarantee you to meet some cool like minded individuals. Will most def be doing it again. 

Thanks Eric for the great hike!!
author: Jordan V.

description:
Get out there people.....walk, hike, yoga, run, whatever it takes to keep those limbs moving, that blood pumping, and the word "alive" the number one way you choose to describe how you feel on any given day.

Christiane led our hiking yoga trek on Saturday morning in Berkeley. We met at a convenient spot on campus a few blocks from BART. I think there were 14 of 17 sign-ups who showed and that's a pretty good turnout. We started on time. Christiane was considerate and waited a few minutes for the last folks to show but when they didn't. she got us out there and moving. And move we did. The Berkeley hills are just that, hills, and Christiane was clear that we would be getting an aerobic workout along the way. Love it! For the first part of the hike, we all stayed pretty much together, and when I stopped to take photos and got behind a bit, I ran to catch up but the group had slowed down to wait. Kind of the "no man left behind" thing. During the hiking, we passed some pretty spectacular homes with lush gardens and expansive lawns, lemon trees, and blossoming cherry. The vista views, which we caught on several occasions, were pretty awesome. It was clear and sunny (but cold and windy at the start so I'm glad I dressed in layers and could adjust as needed). 

We stopped at four different locations along the way to practice various yoga poses, and I appreciated how Christiane gave each of us a bit of personalized attention as well as demonstrating how we would do these poses in an outdoor environment. The mini-mats didn't come out until our final stop when we needed them. I loved doing tree pose facing these enormous trees encircling the park where we stopped. I really felt one with nature and it was an uplifting moment.

I also loved the "take a poem" house. People are so cool. Someone just digs poetry and wants to share it with the world (or at least their little corner of it). We pretty much each went up and took a sheet from the board or basket and tucked it away like a fortune.

We ended about 15 minutes later than the scheduled 11:30 but Christiane let us know when it was 11:30 in case there were people who needed to leave. I don't think anyone wanted to. We really were having a good time.

So, in my opinion, a must do if you are into nature, hiking, yoga, the outdoors, checking out new locations, taking photos, shooting the breeze with new friends.
Well worth the price. Professional, organized company. Great guide. Time well spent.

My friend and I went over to the Sunshine Cafe afterwards for a simple breakfast of eggs, roasted tomatoes and organic brown bread. Very good and I think it cost $7.99.

We're taking the San Francisco hike next month and I'm really looking forward to it.
author: Trish D.

description:
Honestly, I kinda dreaded setting my alarm on a cold and gloomy Saturday to truck it down to the Ferry Building, but I'm really happy I did.  It was totally worth it.  I usually walk up and down a few hills as my Saturday exercise anyway, but the pace that instructor Jennifer Minnetti set made my solo trips feel like a lazy stroll. Add in some perfectly timed simple poses atop pretty peaks, and Hiking Yoga proved to be a surprisingly excellent workout that even got this fitness fan gasping for air. I look forward to doing it again.

Tips: Bring sneaks, water, and a few layers. You warm up pretty fast, but will cool off again during the downhill walk back.
author: Victoria L.

description:
First timer here and very new to Yoga.   

Greg was a great instructor very welcoming and kept the group rolling along.  The experience: group of 20 (including Greg) started at Ferry building and mazed through the Embarcadero to a grassy space I never new existed (fun stuff) then the 1st Yoga.  Off again up some stars and 3 more stopping off spots for more Yoga (Russian Hill).   A great work out, ending at Coit tower (little more Yoga with a partner then we were set free).  

Do something good for yourself try Hiking Yoga.
author: John H.

description:
Amazing workout, excellent instruction.

I grew up in the Bay Area but every hiking yoga adventure with Eric leads to unexplored views and cool city history.  I'd recommend bringing along a friend from out of town or adding it in if you're bored by your current workout routine.  Everyone I've brought along has loved it.

Tips: make sure to dress ready to exercise - it's much  more of a hussle than a meander.  Also, you'll stop at waterfountains so no need to carry a bottle.

Go try hiking yoga - at the end, you'll feel an incredible combination of relaxed, energized and worked.
author: Myla M.

description:
Thank you, Groupon, for introducing me to Hiking Yoga. Two friends and I decided to challenge ourselves to a 9am yoga hike with Eric, and it was DEFINITELY a challenge for my out-of-shape butt!

You don't need to be a hiker or yoga expert to enjoy this. I do yoga about once a week, and the stretches and exercises we did on the hike were on par with what I was used to. I hike....almost never, but sometimes, and it was a big workout. Which is kind of the point, right? I was huffing and puffing, but it got my blood going and I felt great after.

Loved that I explored a neighborhood that I've never walked around much in (my hike was up to Coit Tower but Eric says the routes change each time).

I would highly recommend doing this with a friend from out of town. You get a fun, challenging workout, get to see awesome views of the city, and meet some new people. I can't remember the last time I felt like I accomplished something before 12pm on a Sunday!

Thanks, Eric. I'll be back!
author: Hannah L.

description:
I loved the hiking yoga in Woodside. The trail in Wunderlich Park is very beautiful; and the instructor Emily is nice and fun.
It was a bit difficult at the beginning of the hike and yoga, as my body was trying to warm up; it became enjoyable from the middle and my body is totally alive and energetic for the 2nd part. 
It was a great combination of work out, rejuvenation, and enjoyment of nature.
author: Lorie D.

description: Thank you Greg!  The weather was a little foggy, and you shined light and energy.  The hike was demanding, but the curriculum was a perfect combination with yoga and the opportunity to view this beautiful city.  I highly recommend Yoga Hike to visitors or San Franciscans wanting to see the city in a new way (and get an Ohm in).
author: k s.

description: I did the Embarcadero hike with Wesleigh.  Great workout with a real certified yoga instructor!  Definitely bring water with a travel backpack as Wesleigh moves quickly. (I am from NYC and thought I was a fast walker)  She also has a positive friendly vibe and checks in with everyone at the scenic checkpoints at the top of the hills where we do our Yoga.  Amiable mix of people on the hike from locals to tourists.  Loved the hills, views and learning about my new City.  Looking forward to incorporating this into my weekly workouts.
author: Kristin N.

description: Fun way to see lots of the city and most definitely challenging with the inclines throughout the hike. I was glad I brought my own water bottle:)
author: mary z.

description: I did the Berkeley hike this morning and I loved it!  I want to bring everyone I know to hiking yoga now.  It was very relaxing and energizing at the same time and you get a great tour of Berkeley.  Christiane was great!  I will definitely be back. :)
author: Dominica B.

description: I had my first hiking yoga experience this morning with the amazing Wesleigh. She has such a great energy and is totally encouraging throughout. The yoga is do able by anyone and the hike is invigorating and provides great city views. A must for locals and their guests any weekend in this gorgeous city by the bay :-)
author: Claire M.

description:
Let me start off by saying that in general I loathe hiking.  However, the combination of hiking in the city, getting to see good views with some yoga mixed in was intriguing.  I went to my first session this past weekend on a gorgeous sunny day.  Although I almost quit half way through (clearly I am completely out of shape) - I thought this was awesome.  

We started out at the Ferry Building -  walked super fast through the Embarcadero and around some side streets.  Stopped in a little part to do some yoga warm ups.  Then started our first 'ascent' up some crazy hills and steps.  Stopped again for another yoga session.  Up more crazy stairs!  This time we stopped in a spot with --amazing-- views of the bay and downtown - such a great thing to be doing on a Sunday morning.  I could have done with more stretchy yoga than lunge-y yoga since I was just climbing a million stairs. (But as I said I"m completely out of shape so it was probably fine for everyone else!)  Then more steps!  At the end we go to choose between one last brutal (again, temper 'brutal' with the knowledge of my current fitness level) incline or a relatively flat walk to the ending spot at Grace Cathedral. I obviously chose the flat part.  We ended with a longer yoga session in the Cathedral courtyard which was also beautiful.  

Sure, one could climb all the steps alone and stop and do some yoga along the way - but the group atmosphere made this so much better and the instructor Christiane was knowledgeable and encouraging. She even brought mini yoga mats for everyone to use during the longer session at the end!

I swore half way through that I wouldn't do it again, but I will be going back next weekend.
author: Allison M.

description:
Hiking yoga is incredible!
Not a huge yoga aficionado myself, but a big walker/runner, I really enjoyed the blend of sightseeing, hiking, and yoga. Interesting people for great conversations along the hike as well.
Fun to learn about secret gardens, passageways, and stairs throughout SF, and finding spots with fabulous views. Highly recommend this for tourists looking for an alternative way to learn about the City, and for locals who like to be outside and enjoy our beautiful City!
I can't wait to do it again :)
author: Gillian B.

description:
This was the best and most fun (as well as most rigorous cardio) workout I've ever done. I had never done yoga before, and so despite the basic poses, it was challenging, but the instructor, Sarah, reminded us that it didn't matter if we couldn't do the pose. I did the hike that begins at Cal and heads up into the hills. The hiking was interesting and varied, the views amazing, and I got to see parts of Berkeley that I never knew existed. If you fall behind, you can catch up at the yoga stops, which are a chance to catch your breath and then get a different kind of workout before starting to hike again.
Finally, Sarah is a fantastic instructor - I highly recommend her hikes. Do it now - she's moving out of CA next year.
author: Elizabeth N.

description: I really enjoy this Hiking yoga because I love yoga # 1 and # 2 I get my cardio along with it! The Yoga Instructor Christiane is AWESOME and easy to get along with! I got to see such a beautiful part of Berkeley that I've never seen! I'd say try it if you love nature and like to start your morning off right with doing something active this is the way to go! I will for sure do it again!!!!!!
author: Desirae S.

description:
I came across Hiking Yoga while looking for a drop-in yoga place near our hotel in SF.  It sounded like a great alternative to a sweaty studio, so we decided to give it a shot!  

Eric is super nice, and full of interesting tidbits for locals and tourists alike, as he also leads tours when he is not hiking and yoga-ing.  He leads a vigorous, fast-paced workout that definitely kicked my butt!  

You start with a warm-up, and then proceed to do brisk hiking up a hill, 
with a brief break for yoga, then hiking, then yoga, then hiking, then yoga, with a cooldown at the end.  Eric takes you to spots with gorgeous vistas to do yoga, both well known (Coit Tower) and off the beaten path (serene landings on public walkways with beautiful privately maintained gardens).  

Our group was small, only four people, but Eric said he sometimes gets up to 15+, generally a mix of locals and tourists.  It was nice having a small group and we enjoyed mixing with the locals and getting restaurant recommendations!  

This is NOT a workout for the out of shape.  The hiking component is pretty challenging.  
The route varies from class to class.  If I lived in SF, which, alas, I don't, I would definitely make this part of my regular workout!
author: L C.

description:
